questions.text:
LMN (Lower Motor Neuron) lesion is associated with which one of the following? (INICET NOV 2024)

 

  1. Reduced muscle tone
  2. Spastic paralysis
  3. Babinski sign positive
  4. Fasciculation
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 4

 

Lower motor neuron (LMN) lesions affect the motor neurons in the ventral horn of the spinal cord or their axons in the peripheral nerves. These lesions cause two key features: reduced muscle tone and fasciculation.

 

When there is LMN damage, both alpha and gamma motor neurons are affected. Alpha motor neurons control voluntary muscle contractions, while gamma motor neurons maintain muscle tone. When both are damaged, the patient loses voluntary control of muscles (causing paralysis) and has reduced muscle tone, resulting in flaccid paralysis.

 

Fasciculation is another hallmark of LMN lesions. These are visible, involuntary twitches that occur due to spontaneous discharges from denervated muscle fibers. This phenomenon occurs because of "denervation hypersensitivity" where muscle fibers become hypersensitive after losing their nerve supply.

 

1. Reduced muscle tone: Correct. LMN lesions cause loss of gamma motor neuron activity, which is responsible for maintaining muscle tone. Without this input, muscles become flaccid.

 

4. Fasciculation: Correct. Fasciculations are random, spontaneous contractions of a group of muscle fibers innervated by a single motor unit. They are characteristic of LMN disorders due to denervation hypersensitivity.

 

Other Options:

 

2. Spastic paralysis: Incorrect. Spastic paralysis is characteristic of upper motor neuron (UMN) lesions, not LMN lesions. UMN lesions result in the removal of inhibitory control from higher centers, leading to hyperexcitability of the spinal motor neurons and increased muscle tone. 

 

3. Babinski sign positive: Incorrect. Babinski sign (dorsiflexion of the great toe with fanning of other toes in response to stroking the lateral aspect of the sole) is a pathological reflex seen in UMN lesions, not LMN lesions. It occurs due to the release of the normal flexor plantar response from cortical inhibition.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: All of the following are components of Beck's cognitive theory of depression except: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Introjection

 

Introjection is a psychological process where a person unconsciously adopts the ideas or attributes of other people or objects. This is often discussed in psychoanalytic contexts, not cognitive ones.

 

It involves internalizing aspects of others, such as a child internalizing aspects of a lost parent, leading to complex emotional outcomes, which might contribute to the development of depressive feelings.

 

Other Options:

 

Beck's cognitive theory of depression posits that negative thoughts, cognitive distortions, and dysfunctional beliefs are central to the development and maintenance of depression.

 

Option A. Dysfunctional beliefs are ingrained, maladaptive beliefs developed over time, often from childhood experiences, that can trigger depression when activated by stress.

 

Option B. Cognitive distortions are systematic errors in thinking, such as all-or-nothing thinking or overgeneralization, which negatively influence one's perception of reality.

 

Option D. Automatic negative thoughts are recurring negative thoughts that occur spontaneously and contribute to the persistence of depressive symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Introjection is not a component of Beck's cognitive theory of depression; it is associated with psychoanalytic theory, which focuses on internalized feelings towards an object, such as a parent, and is less commonly used in contemporary understanding of depression.

questions.text: Sterilization technique for the tip of disposable glass pipette is: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Autoclaving and 70% ethanol

 

The most effective sterilization technique for the tip of disposable glass pipettes, as indicated by the available methods, is autoclaving in combination with 70% ethanol.

 

Autoclaving is a reliable method of sterilization that involves exposing the material to high temperature and pressure (121°C at 15 psi) for a specific period, typically 20 minutes. This method effectively kills bacteria, viruses, and spores.

 

Chemical disinfectants

 

 

So, 70% ethanol is widely used as a disinfectant due to its ability to denature proteins and dissolve lipids, making it highly effective at eliminating microbial contamination on glass surfaces.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Microwaving and 95% ethanol: Microwaving is not a standard sterilization method for glass pipettes. Although 95% ethanol can be used for disinfection, it is less effective than 70% ethanol because it evaporates too quickly to kill all microbes thoroughly.

 

Option B. Autoclaving: While autoclaving alone is an effective sterilization method, the question specifies the tip of disposable glass pipettes, where combining it with 70% ethanol enhances the sterilization process.

 

Option D. Hot air oven: A hot air oven can be used for sterilization, but it requires longer exposure times at higher temperatures. This method is less efficient compared to autoclaving combined with ethanol, especially for small, delicate items like pipette tips.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most effective sterilization technique for the tip of disposable glass pipettes is autoclaving combined with 70% ethanol. Autoclaving provides high heat and pressure to eliminate microorganisms, while 70% ethanol ensures thorough disinfection.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding the causes of fall in diastolic blood pressure is correct? (INICET NOV 2024)

 

  1. Loss of sympathetic outflow in the lumbar region
  2. Antagonism of beta-1 adrenergic receptors
  3. Blockade of alpha-1 adrenergic receptors
  4. Antagonism of beta-2 adrenergic receptors
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1 and 3

 

Explanation: 


A fall in diastolic blood pressure primarily occurs due to vasodilation. Two mechanisms listed that cause vasodilation are:

 

1. Loss of sympathetic outflow in lumbar region: Sympathetic system causes vasoconstriction, so its loss leads to vasodilation

 

3. Blockade of alpha-1 adrenergic receptors: Alpha-1 receptors mediate vasoconstriction, so their blockade causes vasodilation

 

Other Options:


2. Antagonism of beta-1 adrenergic receptors: Incorrect. Beta-1 blockade primarily affects heart rate and contractility, leading to decreased systolic blood pressure, not diastolic pressure.

 

4. Antagonism of beta-2 adrenergic receptors: Incorrect. Beta-2 receptors mediate vasodilation, so their blockade would cause vasoconstriction and potentially increase diastolic pressure.

 

Educational Objective:


Diastolic blood pressure is primarily affected by vascular tone - vasodilation decreases it (through loss of sympathetic tone or alpha-1 blockade) while vasoconstriction increases it.

questions.text: Which of the following transport mechanism doesn’t require ATP: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 3

 

The image shows four different transport mechanisms across cell membranes:

 

1. Simple diffusion through membrane: This shows direct diffusion of molecules through the lipid bilayer from high concentration to low concentration. This is also passive transport that doesn't require ATP.

 

2. Simple diffusion through channels: This shows molecules moving through a protein channel from high concentration to low concentration. This is passive transport that follows the concentration gradient without requiring ATP. Channels have gates that simply open or close without configurational changes, allowing molecules to pass according to their concentration gradient.

 

3. Paracellular transport: This shows molecules moving between cells through the spaces between adjacent cells, not through the cells themselves. This is passive movement along the concentration gradient and doesn't require ATP.

 

Other Options:

 

4. Active transport: This shows fewer molecules on one side and more on the other side, indicating movement against the concentration gradient (from low to high concentration). This requires energy in the form of ATP to power the transport proteins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Simple diffusion through membrane, Simple diffusion through channels, Paracellular transport do not require ATP as they represent forms of passive transport, while Active transport requiring ATP

choices.text: It should not be given with erythropoietin
It is given by intravenous route
It is more immunogenic than iron dextran
A single bolus dose is enough for treatment of iron deficiency anemia

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct statement regarding iron isomaltoside? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It is given by intravenous route

 

Explanation:

 

Iron isomaltoside is an intravenous iron preparation that can be given via IV route over approximately 30 minutes. It is characterized by having a very low risk of allergic reactions compared to other IV iron preparations. The drug can be administered in high doses, typically requiring 2-3 doses for complete treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It should not be given with erythropoietin: Incorrect. Iron isomaltoside can be safely given with erythropoietin. It's iron ferromoxitol that should be avoided with erythropoietin.

 

Option C. It is more immunogenic than iron dextran: Incorrect. Iron isomaltoside has very low immunogenicity and is less immunogenic than iron dextran.

 

Option D. A single bolus dose is enough for treatment: Incorrect. Usually 2-3 doses are required for complete treatment, though occasionally one dose might be sufficient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iron isomaltoside is an IV iron preparation characterized by low immunogenicity, compatibility with erythropoietin, and typically requires 2-3 doses for complete treatment.

 

 

Injectable Iron

  • Preparations of injectable iron are:
    • Iron Dextran-Can be given IV as well as IM
    • Iron Sorbital citrate (Used im olnly)
  • Intramuscular iron is given by Z-tract technique to avoid pigmentation

 

Indication of injectable iron:

  • Oral iron cannot be given e.g.
    • Malabsorption
    • Not tolerated (due to GI symptoms)
  • Given with erythropoietin
    • Erythropoietin will stinulate RBC formation and will unmask any iron deficiency 
  • Dose of injectable iron = 4.3 x Hb deficit (g/dl) x body weight (kg)
    • This formula includes the iron required for replenishment of stores also.

questions.text: Calcium deposition is seen in which layer? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) D

 

Calcium deposition occurs primarily in the zone of calcified cartilage, which is represented by option D in the image. This zone is located near the metaphysis of a growing bone, where cartilage is being replaced by bone tissue. The calcification process involves the accumulation of calcium salts in the cartilage matrix, leading to its hardening and subsequent replacement by bone. This is a crucial step in the endochondral ossification process, which allows for the longitudinal growth of bones.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: This layer represents the reserve zone, where chondrocytes are relatively inactive and not yet undergoing proliferation or hypertrophy. Calcium deposition does not occur in this zone.

 

Option B: This layer is the proliferative zone, where chondrocytes are rapidly dividing. While important for bone growth, this zone does not involve calcium deposition.

 

Option C: This is the hypertrophic zone, where chondrocytes increase in size and prepare for calcification. Although it is a precursor to the calcification process, actual calcium deposition occurs in the next zone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The zone of calcified cartilage is where calcium deposition occurs, leading to the hardening of cartilage and its eventual replacement by bone during the growth of long bones.

choices.text: It is quickly concentrated in the brain after IV administration
It shows the phenomenon of redistribution
It has a short duration of action due to rapid renal excretion

questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding thiopentone except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It has a short duration of action due to rapid renal excretion

 

Explanation: 


Thiopentone's short duration of action is due to redistribution, not rapid renal excretion. Due to its high lipid solubility, it rapidly crosses the blood-brain barrier and enters the brain, causing quick onset of anesthesia. However, it then redistributes to other tissues (muscle and fat), leading to a rapid decrease in brain concentration and therefore a short duration of action. The drug remains in the body but is no longer in sufficient concentration in the brain to maintain anesthetic effects.

 

Other Options:


Option A. It is highly lipid-soluble drug : Correct. Thiopentone is highly lipid-soluble, which enables it to rapidly cross the blood-brain barrier.

 

Option B. It is quickly concentrated in the brain after IV administration : Correct. Due to its high lipid solubility, it rapidly enters the brain within seconds of IV administration.

 

Option C. It shows the phenomenon of redistribution : Correct. After initial brain concentration, thiopentone redistributes to other tissues, particularly muscle and fat.

 

Educational Objective: 


Thiopentone's short duration of action is due to redistribution to other tissues, not rapid renal excretion.

 

THIOPENTONE

 

  • T - Thiobarbiturates 
  • H - Hyperthyroidism 
  • I - Inadvertent intra-arterial injection causes vasospasm (treatment - flush with NS, heparin, lignocaine) 
  • O - pH 10.5 (alkaline) 
  • P - pH 
  • Porphyrias (C/I) 
  • Prolongation of QT interval 
  • E - Epilepsy
  • N - Neuroanesthesia (DOC) 
  • T - Termination of action- redistribution

choices.text: A patient who is in acute crisis
A patient who is severely ill with deficient ego functioning
A patient with strong ego and high motivation

questions.text: In which of the following patients, supportive psychotherapy would not be preferred? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A patient with strong ego and high motivation

 

A patient with strong ego and high motivation: Advanced psychoanalysis are advised due to the patient's capacity for deep psychological work. Supportive psychotherapy, which focuses on immediate coping, is considered less effective for this patient.

 

Supportive psychotherapy is aimed at supporting the patient through reassurance, guidance, and a therapeutic relationship without delving deeply into their past or cognitive processes. It is particularly useful for patients in acute crisis, those with cognitive deficits, and severely ill patients with deficient ego functioning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A patient who is in acute crisis: Supportive psychotherapy is highly appropriate as it focuses on providing immediate support and reassurance without exploring complex underlying issues.

 

Option B. A patient with cognitive deficits: These patients may struggle to understand more intricate forms of psychotherapy, making supportive psychotherapy a suitable option to provide essential support and stabilization.

 

Option C. A patient who is severely ill with deficient ego functioning: These patients often have low frustration tolerance and cannot handle the complexities of other forms of therapy, making supportive psychotherapy beneficial to provide stability and support.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Supportive psychotherapy is not preferred for patients with a strong ego and high motivation, as they can handle and benefit from more complex and deeper forms of therapy.

questions.text:
Which of the following contributes to the latent period in a single muscle twitch? (INICET NOV 2024)

 

  1. Excitation-contraction coupling
  2. Opening of sodium channels on NMJ
  3. Transmission of impulse from the site of stimulus to NMJ
  4. Pumping of calcium back to the sarcoplasmic reticulum
questions.solution:
Ans. B) a, b, c

 

The latent period in a single muscle twitch refers to the time delay between the application of stimulus and the beginning of muscle contraction. This period represents several physiological processes that must occur sequentially before the muscle begins to contract.

 

a) Excitation-contraction coupling is a major component of the latent period. It involves the process by which an electrical stimulus (action potential) is converted into a mechanical response (muscle contraction). This includes the action potential reaching T-tubules, activation of dihydropyridine (DHP) receptors, mechanical attachment of T-tubule with L-tubule, opening of ryanodine receptor (RyR) channels, release of Ca²⁺ from sarcoplasmic reticulum, formation of calcium-troponin complex, and displacement of tropomyosin to allow actin-myosin cross-bridge formation.

 

b) Opening of sodium channels at the neuromuscular junction is also part of the latent period. When acetylcholine binds to nicotinic receptors at the motor end plate, it leads to the opening of ligand-gated Na⁺ channels, which generates an action potential in the muscle fiber.

 

c) Transmission of impulse from the site of stimulus to the neuromuscular junction contributes to the latent period as well. This involves the time taken for the action potential to propagate along the nerve fiber from the point of stimulation to the neuromuscular junction.

 

Other Option:

 

d) Pumping of calcium back to the sarcoplasmic reticulum is part of the relaxation phase of muscle contraction, not the latent period. This process occurs after the contraction has already begun and is responsible for muscle relaxation when Ca²⁺ is removed from the sarcoplasm by the SERCA pump (Sarco/Endoplasmic Reticulum Ca²⁺-ATPase).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The latent period in a single muscle twitch includes excitation-contraction coupling, opening of sodium channels at the neuromuscular junction, and transmission of impulse from the site of stimulus to the neuromuscular junction, but does not include calcium reuptake which is part of the relaxation phase.

questions.text: In given image, nucleus of marked nerve is related to (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cervical spinal segment

 

The nerve marked in the image is the phrenic nerve. The phrenic nerve is primarily responsible for innervating the diaphragm, which is crucial for breathing. The mnemonic "3, 4, 5 keeps the diaphragm alive" helps to remember that the phrenic nerve arises from the cervical spinal segments C3, C4, and C5. This nerve travels downward, passing in front of the lung root, to reach the diaphragm.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Midbrain: The midbrain is not involved in the origin of the phrenic nerve. The midbrain primarily deals with functions such as vision, hearing, motor control, sleep/wake, arousal, and temperature regulation.

 

Option B. Pons: The pons is involved in various functions including breathing, communication between different parts of the brain, and sensations such as hearing, taste, and balance. However, it does not give rise to the phrenic nerve.

 

Option C. Medulla: The medulla oblongata regulates vital functions such as heart rate, breathing, and blood pressure. While it contains nuclei for several cranial nerves, it is not the origin of the phrenic nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The phrenic nerve originates from the cervical spinal segments C3, C4, and C5, and is essential for diaphragm movement and breathing.

choices.text: A - Somatostatin B - GH C - GHRH D - IGF1
A - Somatostatin B - GHRH C - GH D - IGF1
A - IGF1 B - GHRH C - GH D - Somatostatin
A - GHRH B - Somatostatin C - GH D - IGF1

questions.text: Identify the hormones represented by the following: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A - Somatostatin B - GHRH C - GH D - IGF1

 

Explanation:

 

A. Somatostatin (Growth Hormone Inhibitory Hormone, GHIH): Somatostatin is released from the hypothalamus and acts as an inhibitory hormone, suppressing the secretion of GH from the pituitary gland.

 

B. Growth Hormone Releasing Hormone (GHRH): GHRH stimulates the pituitary gland to release growth hormone.

 

C. Growth Hormone (GH): GH is released from the somatotrophs of the anterior pituitary gland and has a direct effect on tissues.

 

D. Insulin-like Growth Factor 1 (IGF1): IGF1 is produced in the liver in response to GH and mediates many of the growth-promoting effects of GH, representing the indirect effects of GH.

 

The hypothalamus, often referred to as the "master gland," orchestrates this hormonal cascade by releasing both inhibitory and stimulatory hormones that regulate the secretion of GH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sequence of hormonal regulation in growth hormone release is: Somatostatin (inhibitory) and GHRH (stimulatory) from the hypothalamus regulate GH release from the pituitary, which in turn stimulates IGF1 production in the liver.

questions.text:
Which of the following about the enteric nervous regulation system is false? (INICET NOV 2024)

 

  1. Interstitial cells of Cajal are pacemakers
  2. It can function independently of the brain and spinal cord
  3. All the afferents are from the vagus nerve
  4. Myenteric plexus is in the Lamina propria
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 3, 4

 

The enteric nervous system (ENS) is often referred to as the "brain of the GIT". This complex network of neurons can function autonomously but also communicates with the central nervous system.

 

3. All the afferents are from the vagus nerve: This is FALSE. While the vagus nerve (parasympathetic) does provide afferent innervation to the GIT, it is not the only source. Both the vagus nerve (parasympathetic) and sympathetic nerves provide afferent innervation to the GIT. 

 

4. Myenteric plexus is in the Lamina propria: This is FALSE. The myenteric plexus (also known as Auerbach's plexus) is located between the longitudinal and circular muscle layers of the muscularis, not in the lamina propria which is part of the mucosa. 

 

Correct statements: 

 

1. Interstitial cells of Cajal are pacemakers: This is TRUE. Interstitial cells of Cajal serve as pacemaker cells in the gastrointestinal tract. They produce Basal Electrical Rhythm (BER), which is defined as cyclic fluctuations in the resting membrane potential ranging from -40 to -60 mV. These cells are critical in establishing the intrinsic electrical rhythmicity of the GIT.

 

2. It can function independently of the brain and spinal cord: This is TRUE. The enteric nervous system is capable of functioning independently of the brain and spinal cord. The enteric nervous system is the "brain of GIT," and enteric nervous system connects with the autonomic nervous system, it can work independently through its own neural circuits.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The enteric nervous system is anatomically organized into two major plexuses - the myenteric (Auerbach's) plexus located between longitudinal and circular muscle layers that controls motility, and the submucosal (Meissner's) plexus that regulates secretion. The enteric nervous system receives dual innervation from both sympathetic and parasympathetic (vagal) sources while maintaining the ability to function independently.

questions.text: Marked structure is connected to which part of basal nuclei (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Corpus striatum

 

The marked structure in the provided image is the substantia nigra, identified by its pigmented appearance. The substantia nigra is a crucial component of the basal nuclei, involved in the regulation of movement.

 

The substantia nigra communicates with the basal nuclei through the nigrostriatal pathway, which is composed of dopaminergic neurons connecting the substantia nigra to the corpus striatum. This pathway plays a significant role in the modulation of motor activities and is notably affected in Parkinson's disease.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thalamus: Incorrect because the thalamus primarily acts as a relay station for sensory and motor signals to the cerebral cortex and does not directly connect with the substantia nigra in the context of the basal nuclei.

 

Option B. Subthalamic nucleus: Incorrect because while it is a component of the basal nuclei, it is not the primary structure connected to the substantia nigra in the context of the nigrostriatal pathway.

 

Option C. Globus pallidum: Incorrect because the globus pallidum is involved in regulating voluntary movement but does not have the direct nigrostriatal connection as the corpus striatum does with the substantia nigra.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The substantia nigra is connected to the corpus striatum through the nigrostriatal pathway, which is essential for motor control.

questions.text: Indicated structure gives origin to which of the following fiber (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Dentato-rubral

 

The indicated structure in the provided image is the dentate nucleus. The dentate nucleus is one of the deep cerebellar nuclei and is the largest and most lateral of these nuclei. It is involved in the planning, initiation, and control of voluntary movements.

 

The dentate nucleus gives rise to the dentato-rubral fibers. These fibers project from the dentate nucleus to the red nucleus in the midbrain, playing a crucial role in the coordination of motor movements.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cerebello-rubral: Incorrect because while it involves the cerebellum and red nucleus, the correct specific term for the fiber originating from the dentate nucleus is "dentato-rubral."

 

Option B. Cerebello-reticul: Incorrect because this option refers to fibers connecting the cerebellum to the reticular formation, not specifically involving the dentate nucleus.

 

Option C. Cerebello-vestibul: Incorrect because this refers to fibers connecting the cerebellum to the vestibular nuclei, which are involved in balance and spatial orientation, not related to the dentate nucleus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The dentate nucleus gives rise to the dentato-rubral fibers, which project to the red nucleus and are crucial for motor coordination.

choices.text: It is less than anatomical dead space
It can be measured by spirometry
It is because of inadequate perfusion
It is because of inadequate ventilation

questions.text: Which one of the following is correct about physiological dead space? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is because of inadequate perfusion

 

Physiological dead space refers to the total volume of air that does not participate in gas exchange. It is composed of two components: anatomical dead space and alveolar dead space.

 

Anatomical dead space refers to the volume of air in the conducting airways (from the nose to the terminal bronchioles) that doesn't participate in gas exchange due to the structural anatomy of the respiratory system. The alveolar dead space refers to the volume of air that reaches the alveoli but doesn't participate in gas exchange due to inadequate perfusion of those alveoli.

 

When there is inadequate perfusion (blood flow) to normally ventilated alveoli, a ventilation-perfusion mismatch occurs. This is known as "wasted ventilation" - air reaches the alveoli but since there is insufficient blood flow, the gases cannot be exchanged effectively. This contributes to the physiological dead space.

 

"If there is inadequate perfusion, the alveoli are fine but the problem is in the capillaries. If there is obstruction in the capillaries, fewer molecules of hemoglobin are available to transport oxygen. The remaining oxygen molecules will stay in the alveoli, becoming unexchanged air. This wasted ventilation due to inadequate perfusion adds to physiological dead space."

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is less than anatomical dead space: This is incorrect because physiological dead space equals anatomical dead space in healthy individuals (where alveolar dead space is zero) or exceeds it in pathological conditions (where alveolar dead space is greater than zero). It cannot be less than anatomical dead space because anatomical dead space is determined by the fixed structure of the conducting airways.

 

Option B. It can be measured by spirometry: This is incorrect because spirometry only measures lung volumes and flow rates; it cannot differentiate between exchanged and unexchanged air. Physiological dead space is measured using Bohr's equation, which requires measuring partial pressures of CO2 in exhaled air and arterial blood.

 

Option D. It is because of inadequate ventilation: This is incorrect because inadequate ventilation does not increase dead space. When ventilation is reduced but perfusion is normal, whatever air does reach the alveoli will be completely exchanged due to the preserved perfusion. Inadequate ventilation creates a different type of ventilation-perfusion mismatch called "wasted perfusion" rather than increasing dead space.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Physiological dead space is the sum of anatomical dead space and alveolar dead space, with alveolar dead space occurring primarily due to inadequate perfusion of ventilated alveoli, resulting in wasted ventilation.

questions.text: A 52-year-old female presents with metastatic breast cancer. She has previously undergone treatment with surgery, radiation, and multiple lines of chemotherapy, but her disease has progressed. Genetic testing reveals a BRCA1 mutation, indicating an impaired DNA repair mechanism. Her cancer is classified as HER2-negative and hormone receptor-positive. Given the genetic findings, her oncologist considers using a therapy that targets the PARP enzyme to exploit the DNA repair vulnerability of her cancer cells. Which of the following drugs would be appropriate to prescribe as a PARP inhibitor in this patient? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rucaparib

 

Explanation: 


Rucaparib is a PARP (Poly ADP-Ribose Polymerase) inhibitor. PARP inhibitors work by blocking DNA repair mechanisms in cancer cells. In patients with BRCA mutations (who already have impaired DNA repair), PARP inhibition leads to synthetic lethality and cell death. The name helps identify PARP inhibitors as they end in "parib" (from Poly ADP-Ribose Polymerase inhibitor).

 

Other Options: 


Option A. Palbociclib: Incorrect. This is a cyclin-dependent kinase (CDK) 4/6 inhibitor used in hormone receptor-positive breast cancer. While it might be useful in this patient's case, it is not a PARP inhibitor.

 

Option C. Vorinostat: Incorrect. This is a histone deacetylase inhibitor used in certain hematologic malignancies, not a PARP inhibitor.

 

Option D. Ustekinumab: Incorrect. This is a monoclonal antibody against interleukins used in psoriasis and other autoimmune conditions, not a PARP inhibitor.

 

Educational Objective:


PARP inhibitors (drugs ending in "parib") are particularly effective in cancers with BRCA mutations due to their mechanism of synthetic lethality in cells with impaired DNA repair.
 

Breast Cancer

questions.text: All of the following Decreases GFR except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increased Bowman Oncotic Pressure

 

The GFR is calculated using the formula: GFR = Kf × Net Filtration Pressure (NFP).

 

Net Filtration Pressure is determined by the balance between hydrostatic and oncotic pressures in the glomerular and Bowman's capsule. 

 

The Net Filtration Pressure (NFP) is calculated using the formula: NFP = (HPG - OPG) - (HPB - OPB) Where:

 

  • HPG = Hydrostatic pressure in glomerular capillaries (pushing force, ~60 mmHg)
  • OPG = Oncotic pressure in glomerular capillaries (pulling force, ~32 mmHg)
  • HPB = Hydrostatic pressure in Bowman's capsule (opposing force, ~18 mmHg)
  • OPB = Oncotic pressure in Bowman's capsule (normally negligible, ~0 mmHg)

 

Normally, NFP = (60-32) - (18-0) = 10 mmHg

 

When Bowman's capsule oncotic pressure increases, it pulls more water molecules from the glomerular capillaries into the Bowman's space. This increases filtration, resulting in increased GFR. Proteins in Bowman's capsule would pull more water molecules towards them, which constitutes the filtration process.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreased glomerular coefficient Kf: Incorrect because a decrease in Kf directly reduces GFR according to the formula GFR = Kf × NFP. The glomerular coefficient represents the permeability of the filtration membrane and its surface area.

 

Option B. Increase glomerular oncotic pressure: Incorrect because glomerular oncotic pressure is a pulling force that opposes filtration. When oncotic pressure in glomerular capillaries increases, it holds water within the capillaries, reducing the amount of filtrate formed, thereby decreasing GFR.

 

Option C. Reduced Glomerular Hydrostatic pressure: Incorrect because glomerular hydrostatic pressure is the primary driving force for filtration. A reduction in this pressure means less force is available to push water and solutes across the filtration membrane, resulting in decreased GFR.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

When Bowman's capsule oncotic pressure increases, it pulls more water molecules from the glomerular capillaries into the Bowman's space. This increases filtration, resulting in increased GFR. Proteins in Bowman's capsule would pull more water molecules towards them, which constitutes the filtration process.

questions.text: Catecholamine secretion is increased by all except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hyperglycemia

 

Catecholamines (epinephrine, norepinephrine, and dopamine) are released from the adrenal medulla and sympathetic nerve terminals in response to various physiological stressors. Their secretion is typically increased during situations that trigger the "fight or flight" response.

 

Hyperglycemia does not stimulate catecholamine release because high blood glucose levels don't represent a threat to the body that requires mobilization of energy resources. Catecholamines work to increase blood glucose through glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis. Once glucose levels are already elevated, there's no physiological need for additional catecholamine release.

 

Catecholamine release occurs during hypoglycemia, quiet standing, surgery, smoking, exercise, and is highest in conditions like pheochromocytoma, myocardial infarction, and ketoacidosis. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypoglycemia: Incorrect. Hypoglycemia is a potent stimulus for catecholamine release. When blood glucose levels fall below normal, catecholamines are released to mobilize glucose stores and increase blood glucose through glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis. This is an essential protective mechanism to ensure adequate glucose supply to the brain and other vital organs during periods of low blood glucose.

 

Option C. Smoking: Incorrect. Smoking causes nicotine to enter the bloodstream, which stimulates the adrenal medulla to release catecholamines. The nicotine in cigarettes acts on nicotinic acetylcholine receptors in the adrenal medulla and sympathetic ganglia, triggering the release of epinephrine and norepinephrine. This is part of the physiological response that leads to increased heart rate and blood pressure observed in smokers.

 

Option D. Exercise: Incorrect. Exercise is a significant stimulus for catecholamine release. During physical activity, there's an increased demand for energy and oxygen delivery to working muscles. The sympathetic nervous system is activated, leading to the release of epinephrine and norepinephrine. These catecholamines help in increasing heart rate, blood pressure, and respiratory rate, and they mobilize energy sources to support the increased metabolic demands of exercise.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Catecholamine secretion increases during stress conditions like hypoglycemia, smoking, and exercise, but not during hyperglycemia.

questions.text: Structures passing between marked points A and B? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Stylopharyngeus

 

The stylopharyngeus muscle passes between the superior and middle pharyngeal constrictors. This muscle originates from the styloid process and inserts into the pharyngeal wall. It is innervated by the glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) and functions to elevate the pharynx during swallowing and speaking.

 

 

 

The gaps in the pharyngeal wall and structures passing thorugh them

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Palatopharyngeus: This muscle runs from the soft palate to the pharynx, but it does not pass between the superior and middle pharyngeal constrictors. Instead, it is involved in forming the palatopharyngeal arch.

 

Option C. Stylohyoid: This muscle originates from the styloid process and inserts onto the hyoid bone. It is involved in elevating the hyoid bone during swallowing but does not pass between the superior and middle pharyngeal constrictors.

 

Option D. Mylohyoid: This muscle forms the floor of the mouth and is involved in elevating the floor of the mouth during swallowing. It does not pass between the superior and middle pharyngeal constrictors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The stylopharyngeus muscle passes between the superior and middle pharyngeal constrictors, and it is innervated by the glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX).

choices.text: Blunt object with high force doesn’t stimulate nociceptors
Pinching with serrated object stimulate mechanoceptors but doesn’t cause pain
Sharp pain sensation is carried by type C nerve fiber

questions.text: Mechanical nociceptors and its response to a probe with blunt object, pin prick and tooth forceps with serration is recorded as a output of a force transducer coupled to the stimulator. What will you infer from a given diagram? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Blunt object with high force doesn't stimulate nociceptors

 

Blunt Object:

 

  • Does not produce action potentials in nociceptors
  • Activates mechanoreceptors without triggering pain sensation
  • High force does not necessarily stimulate nociceptive receptors

 

Pin Prick:

 

  • Produces clear action potentials
  • Stimulates nociceptors
  • Sharp stimuli trigger pain receptors

 

Serrated Forceps:

 

  • Produces multiple action potentials
  • Stimulates both mechanoreceptors and nociceptors
  • Causes significant pain response

 

Sharp pain is typically carried by A-delta fibers

 

Slower, diffuse pain is carried by C fibers

 

Nociceptors respond to potentially tissue-damaging stimuli

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nociceptors (pain receptors) respond differentially to various mechanical stimuli - they are activated by sharp objects and pinching/pressure that can potentially damage tissue, but not by blunt pressure even with high force. Fast, sharp pain is transmitted via A-delta fibers, while slow, dull pain is transmitted via C fibers.

questions.text: Structure lies in the floor of inferior horn of lateral ventricle all except (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tail of caudate nucleus

 

The tail of the caudate nucleus is located in the roof of the inferior horn, not the floor.

 

Roof of Inferior horn - Tapetum (part of the corpus callosum), medial part of tail of the Caudate Nucleus and Striate Terminus

 

Floor of Inferior horn – Fimbria, hippocampus, collateral sulcus and collateral eminence.

 

Other Options:

 

The inferior horn of the lateral ventricle is a part of the brain located in the temporal lobe. Structures found in the floor of the inferior horn include the hippocampus, fimbria, and collateral eminence.

 

Option A. Collateral eminence: This is a ridge in the floor of the inferior horn formed by the collateral sulcus.

 

Option B. Hippocampus: A crucial structure for memory conversion, located in the floor of the inferior horn.

 

Option C. Fimbria: A bundle of nerve fibers on the hippocampus that forms part of the floor.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The tail of the caudate nucleus is located in the roof of the inferior horn of the lateral ventricle, not in the floor.

questions.text: Under categorization of triage, the immediately life-threatening injuries would be classified as under the color-coded category: [INICET MAY 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Red

 

The triage system is used in disaster management to categorize victims based on the severity of their condition and the likelihood of survival. Immediate life-threatening injuries, where a person could die or develop severe complications if no intervention is made within 0 to 6 hours, are classified under the Red category. This category is designated for emergent cases that require immediate medical attention to prevent death or severe complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Yellow: This category is for urgent cases where intervention is needed within 6 to 24 hours, such as resuscitation or limb/life-saving surgery. Although these injuries are serious, they are not as immediately life-threatening as those in the Red category.

 

Option C. Green: This category is for non-urgent cases involving minor injuries like fractures, bruises, or lacerations. Patients in this category are ambulatory and can wait for treatment.

 

Option D. Black: This category is for patients who are either deceased or moribund (about to die). It represents the least priority in triage, as these patients have little to no chance of survival.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Triage Tagging system

questions.text: A case of trauma presents to the Emergency with an unknown blood group. Since the patient was hemodynamically unstable, he required immediate blood transfusion. Which blood type can be transfused? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) O positive and O negative

 

In emergency situations where the patient's blood group is unknown, and immediate blood transfusion is required, O negative blood is preferred because it is known as the universal donor. O negative blood can be transfused to any patient regardless of their blood type since it lacks A, B, and Rh antigens, minimizing the risk of adverse reactions.

 

However, if O negative blood is not available, O positive blood can be used, especially in life-threatening situations. While O positive is not universally compatible like O negative, it is still relatively safe for transfusion in emergencies, particularly in patients who are male or non-childbearing females, where the risks of Rh incompatibility are lower.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A positive and O negative: A positive blood can only be given to A positive or AB positive recipients. It is not suitable for unknown blood types in emergencies.

 

Option B. AB negative and O negative: AB negative blood is not a universal donor; it can only be given to AB negative recipients.

 

Option D. A positive and O positive: Similar to option A, A positive is not universally compatible and is therefore not ideal in emergency situations where the blood type is unknown.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Universal blood donor and the safest option: O negative.

questions.text: Reliable feature of some dehydration is: [INICET MAY 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Thirst

 

Thirst is recognized as the most reliable feature of some dehydration. When dehydration begins to set in, the body's initial response is to signal thirst as a way to encourage fluid intake. This response is consistent across various cases of mild to moderate dehydration. Unlike other symptoms, thirst is a direct and early indicator of dehydration that can be easily recognized by the patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Delayed skin pinch: Skin turgor, or the delayed return of the skin to its normal position after being pinched, is influenced by several factors, including nutritional status. This makes it less reliable as a sole indicator of dehydration.

 

Option B. Lethargy: Lethargy can be a symptom of dehydration, but it is difficult to quantify and may vary widely depending on the individual's overall health and the severity of dehydration.

 

Option D. Sunken eyes: The appearance of sunken eyes is quite subjective and often requires the input of a caregiver, such as a parent, to determine whether it is present. It is also not always a definitive sign of dehydration, making it less reliable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thirst is the most reliable and early feature of some dehydration, making it a critical symptom to recognize in assessing dehydration

choices.text: Increase in glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure
Decrease in glomerular capillary oncotic pressure
Increase in renal plasma flow
Increase in Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure

questions.text: Which of the following decreases GFR? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increase in Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure

 

Explanation:

 

Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR) is determined by the balance of pressures acting on the glomerulus. The key pressures involved are the glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure, which drives filtration, and the oncotic pressure, which opposes it. Additionally, the hydrostatic pressure within Bowman's capsule also opposes filtration.

 

Increase in Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure: This is the back pressure exerted by the fluid already in Bowman's capsule. If this pressure increases, it opposes the hydrostatic pressure of the glomerular capillaries, leading to a decrease in GFR. For example, conditions such as ureteric obstruction can increase this pressure, resulting in reduced GFR.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase in glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure: This pressure pushes fluid out of the capillaries and into Bowman's capsule, thus increasing GFR. Therefore, increasing this pressure would not decrease GFR.

 

Option B. Decrease in glomerular capillary oncotic pressure: Oncotic pressure is the "holding" pressure due to plasma proteins. A decrease in this pressure would result in less opposition to filtration, thereby increasing GFR, not decreasing it.

 

Option C. Increase in renal plasma flow: An increase in renal plasma flow generally leads to an increase in GFR because more plasma is being filtered through the kidneys.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An increase in Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure decreases GFR

choices.text: Z line, A band, H zone, I Band
A band, Z line, H zone, M Band
A band, I Band, Z line, H zone
Z line, A band, M Band, H zone

questions.text: Identify the correct labeling (A, B, C, D) in the given image? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Z line, A band, H zone, I Band

 

  • A is the Z line: The light line marking the boundary between sarcomeres
  • B (A band): The darker, thicker region representing myosin filaments
  • C (H zone):  The lighter area between the A bands
  • D (I Band): The lighter area between Z lines containing actin filaments

 

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Its use is contraindicated along with CYP 2C9 inducers
It can be used for resistant malaria
It is approved for treatment of XDR tuberculosis in combination with Bedaquiline and Linezolid
It acts by formation of reactive oxygen species

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding pretomanid? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is approved for treatment of XDR tuberculosis in combination with Bedaquiline and Linezolid

 

Explanation: 


Pretomanid is approved as part of the BPaL (Bedaquiline, Pretomanid, and Linezolid) regime for treating extensively drug-resistant tuberculosis (XDR-TB) and pre-XDR TB in India. This combination therapy represents a significant advancement in treating highly resistant forms of tuberculosis.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Its use is contraindicated along with CYP 2C9 inducers: Incorrect. Pretomanid is metabolized by CYP3A4, not CYP2C9, and is contraindicated with CYP3A4 inhibitors.

 

Option B. It can be used for resistant malaria: Incorrect. Pretomanid is specifically approved for tuberculosis treatment, not malaria.

 

Option D. It acts by formation of reactive oxygen species: Incorrect. Pretomanid acts by releasing reactive nitrogen species (not oxygen), which inhibit mycolic acid synthesis in mycobacteria.

 

Educational Objective: 


Pretomanid is part of the BPaL regimen (Bedaquiline, Pretomanid, and Linezolid) approved for treating XDR-TB and pre-XDR TB, and works through the release of reactive nitrogen species to inhibit mycolic acid synthesis.

 

New Drugs:

 

  1. Bedaquiline: Act by inhibiting ATP synthase enzyme, can result in QT prolongation
  2. Delamanid: Act by inhibiting mycolic acid in mycobacteria, can result in QT prolongation
  3. Pretomanid: Act by inhibiting mycolic acid in mycobacteria

choices.text: b, d and e only
c and e only
a and c only
Only e is correct

questions.text:
Mention the true statement/s about drug resistant malaria: (AIIMS May 2019)

 

  1. It is not present in India.
  2. Quinine with clindamycin or doxycycline is still effective treatment.
  3. Chloroquine with sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine is effective.
  4. Artemether with lumefantrine is useful.
  5. Monotherapy with artemisinin derivatives is not useful due to high risk of recrudescence.
questions.solution:
Ans. A. b, d and e only

 

  • Plasmodium falciparum is now the most common cause of malaria as well as most common cause of drug resistant malaria in India (Option a is false)
  • DOC for multiple drug resistant P falciparum is artemisinin compounds, but they are short acting. The short action is responsible for recrudescence when used as monotherapy in malaria. So they are combined with long acting drugs (known as ACT; Artemisinin based Combination Therapy) like 
  • Artemether + Lumefantrine: DOC in North-Eastern states.
  • Artesunate + Sulfadoxine/Pyrimethamine: DOC all over India except NE states.
  • Artemisinin’s are contraindicated in first trimester of pregnancy; but can be given in second and third trimester.
  • So, if drug resistant malaria occurs in 1st trimester of pregnancy, DOC is Quinine. To reduce its toxicity, we commonly add clindamycin (in pregnancy and children) or doxycycline (in other patients).
  • Chloroquine is not effective in drug resistant malaria. So artesunate (not Chloroquine) is combined with sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine (Option c)  

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is not present in India. False. Drug-resistant malaria is present in India. Plasmodium falciparum, known for drug resistance, is a common cause of malaria in India.

 

Option C. Chloroquine with sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine is effective. False. Chloroquine is not effective in drug-resistant malaria. Artemisinin-based combination therapies (ACTs) are preferred.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Drug-resistant malaria in India is effectively treated with ACTs like Artemether with lumefantrine. Monotherapy with artemisinin derivatives is avoided due to the risk of recrudescence.

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/876-877

questions.text: Mental Health Gap Action (mhGAP) Program does not include: [INICET MAY 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) OCD

 

The Mental Health Gap Action Program (mhGAP) by the World Health Organization (WHO) is designed to scale up services for mental, neurological, and substance use disorders, particularly in low- and middle-income countries. The program focuses on priority conditions that are of high burden and can be managed effectively in primary care settings.

 

The mnemonic "MESSI DAD" can be used to remember the disorders included in the mhGAP program:

 

  • M: Mental disorders in children (Option A)
  • E: Epilepsy
  • S: Suicide
  • S: Schizophrenia and other psychotic disorders (Option B)
  • I: Illicit drug use disorders
  • D: Depression (Option D)
  • A: Alcohol-related disorders
  • D: Dementia

 

Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD) is not included in the list of target conditions under the mhGAP program, which is why it is the correct answer to this question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

OCD (Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder) is not included in the WHO's Mental Health Gap Action (mhGAP) program, which focuses on other high-burden mental health conditions.

questions.text: WMA’s Declaration of Oslo is related to: [INICET MAY 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Therapeutic abortion

 

The World Medical Association's (WMA) Declaration of Oslo is specifically related to the ethical considerations surrounding therapeutic abortion. This declaration emphasizes that medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) should be conducted under specific conditions to ensure it is ethical and safe.

 

The key focus areas of the Oslo Declaration include:

 

MTP must be done only due to:

 

  1. Health Reasons: Therapeutic abortion should only be performed when it is medically necessary for the health of the patient. This may include physical, mental, or social reasons that could adversely affect the well-being of the patient.
  2. Informed Consent: Both the patient and the healthcare provider must fully understand and agree to the procedure. It is essential that both parties are convinced of the necessity and appropriateness of the abortion.
  3. Legal Compliance: The procedure must comply with the local laws governing abortion in the specific region, territory, or country. Legal regulations vary, and it is crucial to adhere to them.
  4. Competent Personnel: The procedure should be carried out by competent surgeons. If the situation allows, trained professional health workers who are competent and authorized by law can also perform the procedure.

 

These principles ensure that therapeutic abortions are conducted in a manner that prioritizes the safety, rights, and well-being of the patient while adhering to ethical and legal standards.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hunger: The Declaration of Oslo is not related to hunger. Hunger and food security issues are addressed by different international organizations and declarations, but not by this specific WMA declaration.

 

Option B. State of prisoners: The Oslo Declaration does not deal with the treatment or state of prisoners. Other international conventions, like the Geneva Conventions, cover the rights and treatment of prisoners.

 

Option C. Ethics in Medical Research: Although the WMA has issued other declarations related to ethics in medical research, such as the Declaration of Helsinki, Nuremberg code and Belmont report.

 

Additional Information

 

Declaration of Geneva: related to the physician's dedication to humanitarian goals of medicine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The WMA’s Declaration of Oslo is specifically related to the ethical guidelines surrounding therapeutic abortion, emphasizing health reasons, informed consent, legal compliance, and the requirement for competent medical personnel.

questions.text: Most common hernia in females (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Indirect inguinal hernia

 

The most common type of hernia in females is the inguinal hernia, and specifically, the indirect inguinal hernia. This can be confusing because femoral hernias are indeed more common in females compared to males, but the indirect inguinal hernia remains the most prevalent overall in females.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Direct inguinal hernia: Incorrect. While inguinal hernias are common, the direct inguinal hernia is less common than the indirect inguinal hernia in both males and females.

 

Option C. Femoral hernia: Incorrect. Femoral hernias are more frequently seen in females compared to males, but they are not the most common type of hernia in females overall.

 

Option D. Obturator hernia: Incorrect. Obturator hernias are rare and not the most common type of hernia in females.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In females, the most common type of hernia is the indirect inguinal hernia, despite femoral hernias being more common in females compared to males.

 

Incidence of Hernia in Females: Indirect inguinal Hernia > Direct inguinal Hernia > Femoral hernia

questions.text: Best test for the diagnosis of disease malaria species is: [INICET MAY 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Thin smear with Giemsa

 

Thin smear with Giemsa stain is the best method for identifying malaria species. This is because thin smears allow for detailed observation of the morphological characteristics of the malaria parasites within red blood cells. The Giemsa stain helps to highlight these features clearly, enabling the identification of the different Plasmodium species based on their unique structures.

 

Thin Smear Usage: Thin smears are used for speciation as they provide a detailed view of the parasites' morphology. This allows for differentiation among the four Plasmodium species (P. vivax, P. falciparum, P. malariae, and P. ovale) by examining the shapes and forms of the parasites within the red blood cells. Thin smears enable the visualization of specific features such as the ring form, amoeboid form, and schizonts in P. vivax, as well as multiple rings and banana-shaped gametocytes in P. falciparum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thick smear with Giemsa: Thick smears are primarily used for quantification of parasites and for genus identification but are not ideal for speciation because the density of the sample can obscure detailed morphological features.

 

Option C. Thin smear with acridine orange: Acridine orange is a fluorescent stain used for rapid screening but is less effective than Giemsa for detailed species identification. It is better suited for initial diagnosis rather than detailed speciation.

 

Option D. QBC (Quantitative Buffy Coat): QBC is a method used for detecting malaria parasites based on fluorescence microscopy. While it is rapid and sensitive, it does not provide detailed morphological information necessary for accurate species identification.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thin smear with Giemsa stain is the best method for detailed malaria species identification due to its ability to highlight specific morphological features of the Plasmodium parasites.

questions.text: Which one of the following curves shows oxygen Hb dissociation after transfusion of stored blood: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) B

 

The oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve after transfusion of stored blood is characterized by two key factors:

 

  1. Low 2,3-Bisphosphoglycerate (2,3-BPG) levels
  2. Lower temperature of stored blood

 

These factors cause a left shift in the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve, which is represented by curve B. The left shift means hemoglobin has a higher affinity for oxygen, making it more difficult to release oxygen to tissues.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Only CD4 contributed to graft rejection significantly
Only CD8 contributed to graft rejection significantly
Both CD4 and CD8 protected against graft rejection significantly
Both CD4 and CD8 contributed to graft rejection significantly

questions.text: For the given Kaplan-Meier curve on the role of T-cells in the allograft rejection process, true statement is: [INICET MAY 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Both CD4 and CD8 contributed to graft rejection significantly

 

The Kaplan-Meier curve presented in this question shows the survival rates of grafts in mice after they were treated with monoclonal antibodies designed to deplete specific T-cells (CD4 and CD8). The survival curves illustrate how the presence or absence of these T-cells affects graft rejection.

 

  • Anti-CD8 Group (Pink Line): The curve for mice treated with anti-CD8 antibodies (which deplete CD8 T-cells) shows a survival rate very similar to the control group. This indicates that the removal of CD8 T-cells alone does not significantly affect graft survival.
  • Anti-CD4 Group (Blue Line): The curve for the anti-CD4 group shows an extended graft survival compared to the control and anti-CD8 groups. This indicates that CD4 T-cells play a more significant role in graft rejection than CD8 T-cells alone. Removal of CD4 prolongs survival from 15 to 30 days.
  • Anti-CD4 + Anti-CD8 Group (Green Line): The green curve represents mice treated with both anti-CD4 and anti-CD8 antibodies. This group shows the longest survival of grafts, extending up to 60 days. The combination of depleting both CD4 and CD8 T-cells significantly delays graft rejection, demonstrating that both types of T-cells are involved in the rejection process.

 

The conclusion drawn from this curve is that both CD4 and CD8 T-cells contribute to graft rejection, and their combined effect is more pronounced than the effect of either cell type alone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Both CD4 and CD8 T-cells are crucial contributors to the allograft rejection process, and their combined depletion significantly prolongs graft survival.

choices.text: Superior & medial quadrant has more tissue
Axillary tail of Spence crosses anterior axillary fold
Nipple is located at 4th intercostal space in most of the females

questions.text: True statement regarding the breast (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Axillary tail of Spence crosses anterior axillary fold

 

The axillary tail of Spence is an extension of the breast tissue that extends into the axilla (armpit area). It passes through the anterior axillary fold, which is a region near the front of the underarm. This anatomical feature is important for surgical considerations, particularly in breast surgeries and examinations for breast cancer.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior & medial quadrant has more tissue: This statement is incorrect. The superior and medial quadrant of the breast does not have more tissue compared to other quadrants. The distribution of tissue in the breast is such that no specific quadrant is known to universally have more tissue in every individual.

 

Option B. 10 lobules are present: This statement is incorrect. The human breast typically contains around 15-20 lobules, not just 10. These lobules are responsible for the production of milk and are connected to ducts that lead to the nipple.

 

Option D. Nipple is located at 4th intercostal space in most of the females: While the nipple is located at the level of the 4th intercostal space in males. In females, its position can vary among individuals due to the pendulous nature of the breast. Factors such as age, breast size, and body position can influence the exact location of the nipple.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The axillary tail of Spence crosses the anterior axillary fold, which is an important anatomical detail relevant in breast examinations and surgeries.

questions.text: Match the following (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-a, 2-b, 3-c, 4-d

 

  1. Eonism: a. Sexual gratification by cross-dressing. This term is used to describe individuals who derive sexual pleasure from dressing in clothes traditionally worn by the opposite gender.
  2. Frotteurism: b. The act of rubbing one's genitals against a non-consenting person, usually in a crowded place, such as public transport. It is considered a paraphilic disorder.
  3. Necrophilia: c. Sexual stimulation by corpses. This is a rare and extreme paraphilia where individuals are sexually aroused by deceased bodies.
  4. Algolagnia: d. Sexual gratification in inflicting or suffering pain. This can involve either sadism (inflicting pain) or masochism (receiving pain) as part of sexual activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eonism is sexual gratification by cross-dressing, frotteurism involves rubbing genitals against a non-consenting person, necrophilia is sexual stimulation by corpses, and algolagnia involves sexual gratification from inflicting or suffering pain.

questions.text: Artery supplying near marked structure is (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anterior interventricular artery

 

The anterior interventricular artery, also known as the left anterior descending artery (LAD), supplies the anterior portion of the interventricular septum. This artery runs along the anterior interventricular groove and is critical in providing blood to the front part of the heart, including the septum and the left ventricle. The LAD is often referred to as the "widowmaker" artery because blockage of this artery can lead to severe myocardial infarction, which is often fatal.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left circumflex artery: This artery supplies the lateral and posterior walls of the left ventricle but does not supply the anterior interventricular septum.

 

Option B. Left marginal artery: This artery branches off the circumflex artery and supplies the left ventricle's lateral wall, but it does not supply the interventricular septum.

 

Option D. Posterior interventricular artery: This artery supplies the posterior third of the interventricular septum but not the anterior portion. It runs in the posterior interventricular groove.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anterior interventricular artery (LAD) supplies the anterior two-thirds of the interventricular septum and is critical for heart function, making it a key vessel in coronary circulation.

questions.text: Peripheral chemoreceptors are most sensitive to which one of the following? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypoxia

 

Peripheral chemoreceptors, located in the carotid bodies (innervated by the glossopharyngeal nerve/9th cranial nerve) and aortic bodies (innervated by the vagus nerve/10th cranial nerve), are primarily sensitive to changes in blood oxygen levels. While they do respond to multiple stimuli, they are most sensitive to decreases in PO₂ (hypoxia).

 

The peripheral chemoreceptors respond to:

 

  • Decreased PO₂ (less than 60 mmHg) - primary stimulus
  • Increased PCO₂
  • Increased H⁺ (acidosis)

 

"oxygen sensitive potassium channels" in the glomus cells of peripheral chemoreceptors make them highly responsive to decreases in oxygen. When comparing sensitivity, if you increase carbon dioxide by 1% or decrease oxygen by 1%, the hypoxic response will be much stronger than the hypercapnic response.

 

While CO₂ is the main overall stimulus for respiration (as it affects both central and peripheral chemoreceptors), when specifically discussing peripheral chemoreceptors alone, hypoxia is the stimulus to which they are most sensitive.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CO₂: While peripheral chemoreceptors do respond to increases in PCO₂, they are less sensitive to CO₂ than to hypoxia. CO₂ primarily stimulates central chemoreceptors in the ventral medulla which respond to changes in H⁺ ion concentration in the CSF. CO₂ is the main stimulus for respiration overall, but not the most sensitive stimulus for peripheral chemoreceptors specifically.

 

Option C. Alkalosis: Peripheral chemoreceptors are not significantly stimulated by alkalosis (increased pH or decreased H⁺ concentration). Alkalosis tends to decrease respiratory drive rather than stimulate it.

 

Option D. Acidosis: Although peripheral chemoreceptors do respond to acidosis (decreased pH, increased H⁺), they are still more sensitive to hypoxia. Acidosis is a secondary stimulus for peripheral chemoreceptors compared to hypoxia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Peripheral chemoreceptors (carotid and aortic bodies) are most sensitive to hypoxia (decreased PO₂ less than 60 mmHg), despite also responding to increases in PCO₂ and H⁺ (acidosis).

questions.text: A young male weighing 46 kg was treated with a drug. It has a Vd of 6 L/kg and clearance of 4.6 L/hour. What is the approximate half-life of this drug? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 40 hours

 

Explanation: 


The half-life can be calculated using the formula:

 
t1/2 = 0.693 × Vd/Clearance

 

  • Vd given is 6 L/kg, so total Vd = 6 × 46 = 276 L
  • Clearance = 4.6 L/hour Therefore: t1/2 = 0.693 × 276/4.6 ≈ 0.693 × 60 ≈ 40 hours


Educational Objective: 


The formula for calculating half-life (t1/2 = 0.693 × Vd/Clearance) and remember to account for total Vd when given in L/kg by multiplying with body weight.

questions.text: Identify the vertebral level of section in given image? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) T9

 

The provided image shows a cross-sectional anatomy where key structures such as the liver, stomach, heart, and lungs are visible. At the T9 vertebral level, the liver and stomach are seen prominently, with the heart also visible, indicating that the section is at the level where these thoracic and upper abdominal structures overlap. The presence of the lungs further supports that this is a thoracic level.

 

 

 

Cross sectional anatomy of ABDOMEN:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. T10: While the T10 level also shows some of the same structures, the visibility and position of the liver, stomach, heart, and lungs in this image are more indicative of T9.

 

Option C. T11: At the T11 level, the kidneys start to become visible, and the heart is usually not as prominent as it is at the T9 level.

 

Option D. T12: The T12 level typically shows the kidneys more clearly and does not include as much of the heart and upper liver as seen in the provided image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The T9 vertebral level in cross-sectional anatomy images often shows the liver, stomach, heart, and lungs, making it a key point for identifying these structures.
